resources.string: If you have any comments, questions, complaints please send an email to: finances@codelemma.com.
We will answer you back as soon as we can.\n\nPlease, rate FinanceSim in GooglePlay.

FinanceSim simulates your future financial situation based on all the earnings (capital and non-capital income) and spendings (debts and expenses) you incur each month. It generates simulations showing the rate of growth of your assets and liabilities. It will tell you: 
 - when you are going to get your (first) million 
 - how fast will your 401(k) grow 
 - what is the comparative return of all your assets (investments)
 - and more.
Constant inflation, constant return from 401(k) and other investments or savings account, and constant tax rate.
FinanceSim is not an expense, income or debt tracker. It uses the data you may track elsewhere, though, as input for the simulations.

- ability to add 401(k) Roth pension plan,
 - year by year simulation resolution,
 - ability to add bond investments,
 - and more.
I\'ll be happy to hear from you at: finances@codelemma.com

FinanceSim serves informative functions only and may not be used as a replacement of legal advice. Although every precaution has been taken in preparation of the app, the author assumes no responsibility for errors or omissions and the app is provided without any guarantees, conditions or warranties as to its accuracy.
%s chart empty.\n\n No %s data has yet been added.
%s table empty.\n\n No %s data has yet been added.
Here no input is necessary. All your income, expenses, savings, and debts will be accounted for automatically.
Cashflow chart and table depicts monthly inflow and outflow of your capital.
Here no input is necessary. All your income, expenses, savings, and debts will be accounted for automatically.
Net worth chart and table show your accumulated savings, total debt and their difference.
Monthly expenses, travel, insurance, rent, etc.
Here add any regular source of income (eg. salary, returns from renting a flat, dividends, etc.).
Income per year - gross yearly income.
Rise per year - estimated yearly payment increase rate.
Payment frequency - number of payments in a year (12 - monthly, 13 - monthly with an additional payment at the end of the year).
Start date - date of income commencement. For current salary, specify current month and year.
Income term - number of years to gather income.
Monthly extra payment - amount added to your monthly payment.
Start date - date of loan commencement.
Downpayment - amount paid in cash at the onset of the loan as a percentage of the purchased property price.
Mortgage term - the length of time the mortgage terms and conditions (including interest rate) are in effect.
Property insurance - insurance against risks to the property.

PMI - Private Mortgage Insurance, paid to the lender if the downpayment is lower than 20% of the purchased property price or when the loan-to-value ratio is lower than 80 percent. Loan-to-value ratio is a ratio of the loan to the value of an asset purchased.
Start date - date of loan commencement.
Amount - average/estimated expense in the specified period of time.
Inflation rate - estimated mean yearly rate of inflation.
Frequency - number of times per year the expense is made.
Start date - date of expense commencement.
Contribution (% of excess money, see HELP)
Current amount - current balance on your account.
Tax rate - tax rate on the interests.
Interest payment frequency - how often the interests are paid to your account (usu. monthly).
Contribution - what percentage of your total monthly excess money (capital and non-capital income minus expenses, debt rates, retirement plan account) you want to put into the savings account.
Current amount - current balance on your account.
Tax rate - tax rate on the interests.
Payment frequency - how often the interests are paid to your account (usually monthly).
Current balance - current balance on your 401(k) account.
Salary - salary account associated with the 401(k) plan.
Your contribution - your annual contribution rate to the account.
Employer match - your employer\'s contribution match rate.
Term - number of years to save.
Tax rate at withdrawal - estimated tax rate at withdrawal.
Expected return (per year) - expected rate of return from the invested 401(k) earnings.
Start date - date of 401(k) plan commencement (has to start after the salary start date).
Here input your regular income sources (salary, income from renting an apartment, etc.)
The chart shows a net and gross income in a given month.
If 401(k) is associated with a given income account, the 401(k) contribution is subtracted from the account before tax.

Here input your regular expenses, such as monthly spendings, insurance, house or apartment rent, yearly travel budget, etc. \n\nThe submitted amounts are used as starting points in projecting your future expenses taking into account inflation, which is assumed to be constant over the years.
The chart shows the rise of monthly expenses over years due to inflation.
Each month the expenses you incur rise due to inflation. They will be lower if inflation you submitted is negative.

Here input your bank and retirement plan accounts data. 

::: CHECKING ACCOUNT:::
It is a fixed account used in FinanceSim to deposit all of the remaining monthly income (capital and non-capital) after it has been partitioned into expenses, savings accounts, 401(k) accounts, and debt rates. The interests are compounded continuously. 

::: SAVINGS ACCOUNT:::
In a savings account you can store a given percentage of your excess money (that is the money remaining after it has been partitioned into expenses, 401(k) accounts, savings accounts, and debt rates). Compounding is continuous. 

::: 401(K) ACCOUNT :::
Contributons to this 401(k) account plan are made on a pre-tax basis so the earnings are tax-deferred. Tax is subtracted from the 401(k) earnings on withdrawal and deposited in the checking account.
The chart shows the rise of amount of money in a given account over years.

::: CHECKING AND SAVINGS ACCOUNT :::

Deposit is an amount of money saved monthly into an account. For a savings account it is a percentage (specified by the user) of the excess money, which is the amount left after expenses are made, debts and retirement plans served. For a checking account it is all the money that remain after all the monthly expenses, debts, retirement contributions, and savings and made. 

Total is a cumulative amount of money stored in an account at a given time. 

::: 401(K) :::

Employee and Employer contrib are the monthly contributions to the account from the employee and employer.

::: LOAN ::: 
This is the most typical loan payment type (a fully amortizing payment), in which each monthly rate has the same value over time. Interests are compounded monthly. 

::: MORTGAGE :::
This is a fixed rate mortgage, which has a fixed interest rate through the entire term of the loan. As a result payment amounts and the duration of the loan are fixed. It also assumes the typical case when PMI (private mortgage insurance) is paid until loan-to-value ratio reaches 80%. Interests are compounded monthly.
Total interest is a cumulative amount of interests you\'ve paid up to a given point in time. \n\nOutstanding loan is the loan amount you still need to pay off.

::: LOAN :::

Principal is a part of a monthly payment of the amount borrowed. 

Interest is a monthly loan fee. 

To calculate monthly payment add principal and interest. 

Total interest is a cumulative amount of interests you've paid up to a given point in time. 

Remaining amount is the loan amount you still need to pay off.

::: MORTGAGE :::

Principal is a part of monthly payment of the amount borrowed. 

Interest is a monthly loan fee. 

Tax, PMI, insurance are extra property tax, Private Mortgage Insurance, property insurance paid monthly. 

To calculate monthly payment add principal, interest and the extra costs. 

Total interest is a cumulative amount of interests you've paid up to a given point in time. 

Remaining amount is the loan amount you still need to pay off.
Cashflows \nShow the distribution of your monthly earings, savings and spendings.

Net income is a sum of all your net income sources in a given month.

Capital gains is a sum of the interests and earnings made in a given month, excluding 401(k) earnings (which are deposited in a lump sum to the Checking Account at withdrawal). 

Total expenses is a sum of all the spendings made in a given month. 

Debt service is a sum of your monthly debt payments. 

Saved is the amount of money put away into bank accounts (checking, savings, etc.) in a given month. It includes 401(k) earnings deposited in a lump sum at withdrawal.

Net income is a sum of all your net income sources in a given month.

Capital gains is a sum of the interests and earnings made in a given month, excluding 401(k) earnings (which are deposited in a lump sum to the Checking Account at withdrawal). 

Total expenses is a sum of all the spendings made in a given month. 

Debt service is a sum of your monthly debt payments. 

Saved is the amount of money put away into bank accounts (checking, savings, etc.) in a given month. It includes 401(k) earnings deposited in a lump sum at withdrawal. 

The total of all these amounts in a given month should be 0.

Savings is the sum of money accumulated up to a given point in time. This includes 401(k) savings, while the tax on the 401(k) earnings is subtracted from the savings at 401(k) withdrawal time. 

Outstanding debts is a sum of all your debts at a given point in time. 

Net worth = savings - debts.
FinanceSim projects your future financial situation based on your current earnings and spendings.\n
enter or modify input data (income, expenses, savings, debts)
\nPlease, rate the app in Google Play.
To add a 401(k) account, please add income data first.
